intro: Cinchona succirubra var. cuchicara, commonly known as the Cuchicara quinine tree, is a species native to the Andean regions of South America. It is a member of the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its large, elliptical leaves and showy, fragrant flowers. The plant is notable for its bark, which contains compounds used in the production of quinine, historically important for treating malaria. It thrives in humid, tropical climates and is often found in secondary forests and along riverbanks. Due to its medicinal value, it is also cultivated in botanical gardens and conservation programs.
